answers.text: when learning new information makes it harder to recall old information
where prior learning disrupts recall of new information

qas.question: What is a term used to describe being able to learn something quicker due to an older ability?

plausible_answers.text: when learning new information makes it harder to recall old information
where prior learning disrupts recall of new information

qas.question: What is the phenomenon when learning Latin makes it harder to learn French?
What disrupts recall of old information?

context: Interference <a0_0><b4_0>can hamper memorization and retrieval<b4_0/><a0_0/>. There is retroactive interference, <a1_0><b5_0>when learning new information makes it harder to recall old information<b5_0/><a1_0/> and proactive interference, <a2_0><b6_0>where <b8_0>prior learning<b8_0/> disrupts recall of new information<b6_0/><a2_0/>. Although interference can lead to forgetting, it is important to keep in mind that there are situations when old information can facilitate learning of new information. Knowing Latin, for instance, can help an individual learn a related language such as French – this phenomenon is known as <a3_0><b7_0>positive transfer<b7_0/>.
